editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.head: ‚ùß A Prayer, conteining al≈øo a Confe≈øsion of ≈øinnes. Which is to be ≈øaid after the Letany, aswell vpon Sundayes, as Wedne≈ødaies and Fridaies.
div.p:
O Almightie, mo≈øt iu≈øt and mercifull God, we here acknowledge our ≈øelues mo≈øt vnwoorthy to lift vp our eies vnto heauen, for our con≈øcience doth accu≈øe vs, & our ≈øins do reprooue vs. Wee knowe al≈øo that thou, Lord, being a iu≈øt iudge, mu≈øt needes puni≈øh the ≈øinnes of them which tran≈øgre≈ø≈øe thy Lawe. And when wee con≈øider and examine all our whole life, wee finde nothing in our ≈øelues, that de≈øerueth anie other thing but eternall damnation. But becau≈øe thou, O Lorde, of thy vn≈øpeakable mercie, ha≈øt commaunded vs in all our nece≈ø≈øities to call onelie vpon thee, and ha≈øt al≈øo promi≈øed, that thou wilt heare our Prayers, not for anie our de≈øert (which is none) but for the merits of thy Sonne our onely Sauiour Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, whome thou ha≈øt ordeined to be our onlie Mediatour and Interce≈ø≈øour. We lay away all confidence in man, and doe flee to the throne of thy onelie mercie, by the interce≈ø≈øion of thy only Sonne our Sauiour Ie≈øu Chri≈øt. And fir≈øt of all, wee doe mo≈øt lament and bewayle, from the bottome of our
hearts, our vnkindne≈ø≈øe and vnthankefulne≈ø≈øe towardes thee our Lorde, con≈øidering that be≈øides tho≈øe thy benefites which wee enioy as thy creatures, common with all mankinde, thou ha≈øt be≈øtowed many and ≈øingular ≈øpeciall benefites vpon vs, which wee are not able in heart to conceyue, much le≈ø≈øe in wordes worthily to expre≈ø≈øe. Thou ha≈øt called vs to the knowledge of thy Go≈øpell. Thou ha≈øt relea≈øed vs from the harde ≈øeruitude of Sathan. Thou ha≈øt deliuered vs from all horrible and execrable Idolatry, wherein wee were vtterly drowned, and ha≈øt brought vs into the mo≈øt cleare and comfortable light of thy ble≈ø≈øed worde, by the which wee are taught how to ≈øerue and honour thee, and howe to liue orderly with our neighbours in trueth and veritie. But wee mo≈øt vnmindefull in times of pro≈øperitie, of the≈øe thy great benefites, haue neglected thy commandements, haue abu≈øed the knowledge of thy Go≈øpell, and haue followed our carnall libertie, and ≈øerued our owne lu≈øtes, and through our ≈øinnefull life, haue not wor≈øhipped and honoured thee as we ought to haue done. And nowe, O Lorde, being euen compelled with thy correction, wee doe mo≈øt humbly confe≈ø≈øe that wee haue ≈øinned, and haue mo≈øt grieuou≈øly offended thee by many and ≈øundry wayes. And if thou, O Lorde, woulde≈øt now being prouoked with our di≈øobedience, ≈øo deale with vs as thou might, and as we haue de≈øerued, there remayneth nothing els to be looked
for, but vniuer≈øall and continual plagues in this world, and hereafter eternall death and damnation, both of our bodies and of our ≈øoules. For if we ≈øhoulde excu≈øe our ≈øelues, our owne con≈øciences would accu≈øe vs before thee, and our owne di≈øobedience and wickedne≈ø≈øe woulde beare witne≈ø≈øe again≈øt vs. Yea, euen thy plagues and puni≈øhmentes which thou doe≈øt nowe lay vpon vs in ≈øundry places, doe teach vs to acknowledge our ≈øinnes. For ≈øeeing, O Lord, that thou art iu≈øt, yea euen iu≈øtice it ≈øelfe, thou puni≈øhe≈øt no people without de≈øert. Yea, euen at this pre≈øent O Lorde, wee ≈øee thy hand terribly ≈øtretched out to plague vs, and puni≈øh vs. But although thou ≈øhoulde≈øt puni≈øh vs more grieuou≈øly then thou ha≈øt done, and for one plague ≈øend an hundreth, if thou ≈øhoulde≈øt powre vpon vs all tho≈øe thy te≈øtimonies of thy mo≈øt iu≈øt wrath, which in times pa≈ø≈øed thou powred≈øt on thy owne cho≈øen people of I≈ørael: yet ≈øhoulde≈øt thou doe vs no wrong, neyther could wee deny but wee had iu≈øtly de≈øerued the ≈øame. But yet, O mercifull Lord, thou art our God, and wee nothing but du≈øt and a≈øhes: Thou art our creatour, and we the worke of thy handes: Thou art our pa≈øtor, we are thy flocke: Thou art our redeemer, and we thy people redeemed: Thou art our heauenly father, we are thy children, wherefore puni≈øh vs not, O Lorde, in thine anger, but cha≈øten vs in thy mercy. Thy people of I≈ørael often times offended thee, and thou mo≈øt iu≈øtly afflicted them: but as oft as they returned to thee, thou didde≈øt receiue them to mercie. And though their ≈øinnes were neuer ≈øo great, yet thou alwayes turned≈øt away thy wrath from them, and the puni≈øhment prepared for them, and that for thy couenant ≈øake, which thou made≈øt with thy ≈øeruantes, Abraham, I≈øaac, and Iacob. Thou ha≈øt made the ≈øame couenant with vs (O heauenly Father) or rather a couenant of more excellencie and efficacie, and that namely through the mediation of thy deare Sonne Ie≈øus Chri≈øt our Sauiour, with who≈øe mo≈øt precious blood, it plea≈øed thee that this couenant ≈øhould be, as it were, written, ≈øealed, and confirmed. Wherfore, O heauenly Father, we nowe ca≈øting away all confidence in our ≈øelues or any other creature, doe flee to this mo≈øt holy couenant & Te≈øtament, wherein our Lord & Sauiour Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, once offered him≈øelfe a ≈øacrifice for vs on the cro≈ø≈øe, hath reconciled vs to thee foreuer. Receaue vs al≈øo into thy heauenly defence, and gouerne vs by thy holy ≈øpirite, to frame in vs a newene≈ø≈øe of life, therein
to laude and magnifie thy ble≈ø≈øed name for euer, and to liue euery of vs according to the ≈øeuerall ≈øtate of life whereunto thou Lorde ha≈øt ordeyned vs in godly feare & trembling before thee. And although we are vnworthy (O heauenly father) by meanes of our former foule life, to craue any thing of thee: yet becau≈øe thou ha≈øt commaunded vs to pray for all men, wee mo≈øt humbly here vpon our knees be≈øeech thee, ≈øaue and defende thy holy Church, be mercifull, O Lorde to all common weales, Countreyes, Princes, and Magi≈øtrates, and e≈øpecially to this our Realme, and to our mo≈øt gracious Queene and gouernour Queene Elizabeth, increa≈øe the number of godly Mini≈øters, indue them with thy grace to bee found faithfull and prudent in their office, defend the Queenes Maie≈øties Councell, and all that be in aucthoritie vnder her, or that ≈øerue in any place by her commaundement for this Realme. We commend al≈øo to thy fatherly mercy, all tho≈øe that be in pouertie, exyle, impri≈øonment, ≈øicknes, or any other kinde of aduer≈øitie, and namely tho≈øe whome thy hand now hath touched with any contagious and dangerous ≈øickene≈ø≈øe, which wee be≈øeech thee, O Lorde, of thy mercie (when thy ble≈ø≈øed will is) to remoue from vs, and in the meane time, graunt vs grace and true repentance, ≈øtedfa≈øt faith, and con≈øtant patience, that whether we liue or dye, wee may alwayes continue thine, and euer prai≈øe thy holy name, and be brought to the fruition of thy Godhead. div.p:
O Eternall and euerliuing God, mo≈øt mercifull Father, which of thy great long ≈øuffering and patience, ha≈øt hitherto ≈øuffered and borne with vs mo≈øt mi≈øerable offenders, who haue ≈øo long ≈øtrayed out of thy way, and broken all thy lawes and commaundements, and haue, neither by thy manifolde benefites be≈øtowed vpon vs vnworthie and vnthankefull ≈øinners, nor by the boyce of thy ≈øeruauntes and preachers, by continuall threatninges out of thy holy word, hitherto ben moued, either as thy children, of loue to returne vnto thee our mo≈øt gratious Father, either for feare of thy iudgementes, as humble and lowely ≈øeruants to turne from our wickedne≈ø≈øe.
